awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Intrusion Detection and Resilience Against Attacks in Cyber and Cyber-Physical Control Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a novel methodology for designing secure cyber and cyber-physical systems that can detect attackers and protect against malicious behavior after the system has been compromised.  
Networked control systems contain actuators and sensors that can be compromised by a malicious attacker intent on altering the system behavior by corrupting sensor values or actuator commands, thereby enabling or forcing the execution of unsafe behavior. The PIs investigate the intrusions that resulted in compromised system components (sensors or actuators) and design remedial control strategies that not only combat malicious attackers upon detection of intrusion but are also resilient to potential intrusions, thereby preventing damage from being inflicted upon the system. 

The technical approach has its foundations in the theories of diagnosability, opacity, and supervisory control of discrete-state event-driven dynamic systems. The research plan to the problems of intrusion detection and resilience against attacks contains a creative blend of these theories with game-theoretic approaches to reactive synthesis problems, in order to capture the dynamic game between the control system (acting as the defender) and the attacker. The goal of the defender is to optimize its trade-off between functionality and vulnerability. Given the prevalence of feedback control loops in cyber and cyber-physical systems, the methodology being developed will impact a large class of technological systems that are of great societal importance.

por.por_cntn:
Feedback control of dynamic systems is an essential element of our technological society. It is impossible to find a technological system, either cyber or cyber-physical, that does not contain a feedback loop somewhere in its design. The aim of this project was to advance the science of cybersecurity for cyber and cyber-physical control systems that involve a networked system that interacts with its environment through a set of potentially vulnerable sensors and actuators. The actuators and sensors can be compromised by a malicious attacker intent on altering the system behavior and causing physical damage by corrupting sensor values or actuator commands, or intent on inferring critical information about the system. Novel methodologies were developed to analyze and design cyber and cyber-physical control systems that can detect malicious attackers and protect against unsafe behavior after the system has been compromised. A new mechanism of obfuscation was also developed and tested to prevent the system from revealing critical information to malicious eavesdroppers.

Using a formal model-based approach, the following problems were investigated: (i) Detection of intrusions that result in compromised system components (sensors or actuators); (ii) Synthesis of obfuscation strategies that protect critical system information from malicious observers; (iii) Design of remedial control strategies that combat malicious attackers upon detection of intrusion; and (iv) Design of control strategies that are resilient to potential intrusions and prevent damage from being inflicted upon the system. 

The technical approach had its foundations in the theories of diagnosability, opacity, and supervisory control of discrete-state event-driven dynamic systems. The methodologies for intrusion detection, obfuscation, and resilience against attacks that were developed blend these theories with game-theoretic approaches to reactive synthesis problems, in order to capture the dynamic game between the control system (acting as the defender) and the attacker. The goal of the defender is to optimize its trade-off between functionality and vulnerability, while the goal of the attacker is to inflict damage or infer system secrets while avoiding detection.

Results were published in archival journals and conference proceedings. Software tools implementing the methodologies that were developed are publicly available from the project website maintained at the University of Michigan. This project contributed to the training of several graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and undergraduate students at the University of Michigan in the important area of cybersecurity of control systems.

The research conducted in this project resulted in formal methodologies and associated software tools that will have a significant impact on a large class of technological systems that are of great societal importance. The project also connected security and privacy research in computer science with control engineering research on fault detection and resilient supervisory control, thereby helping to build a bridge between these two disciplines.
